question: what is amazon rds?
answer: amazon relational database service (amazon rds) is a managed service that makes it easy to set up, operate, and scale a relational database in the cloud

question: which relational database engines does amazon rds support?
answer: amazon rds supports amazon aurora, mysql, mariadb, oracle, sql server, and postgresql database engines

question: when would i use amazon rds vs. amazon ec2 relational database amis?
answer: amazon web services provides a number of database alternatives for developers

question: how do i get started with amazon rds?
answer: to sign up for amazon rds, you must have an amazon web services account

question: are there hybrid or on-premises deployment options for amazon rds?
answer: yes, you can run rds on premises using amazon rds on outposts and amazon rds on vmware

question: what is a database instance (db instance)?
answer: you can think of a db instance as a database environment in the cloud with the compute and storage resources you specify

question: how do i create a db instance?
answer: db instances are simple to create, using either the aws management console, amazon rds apis, or aws command line interface

question: how do i access my running db instance?
answer: once your db instance is available, you can retrieve its endpoint via the db instance description in the aws management console, describedbinstances api or describe-db-instances command

question: how many db instances can i run with amazon rds?
answer: by default, customers are allowed to have up to a total of 40 amazon rds db instances

question: how do i import data into an amazon rds db instance?
answer: there are a number of simple ways to import data into amazon rds, such as with the mysqldump or mysqlimport utilities for mysql; data pump, import/export or sql loader for oracle; import/export wizard, full backup files (

question: what is a maintenance window? will my db instance be available during maintenance events?
answer: the amazon rds maintenance window is your opportunity to control when db instance modifications, database engine version upgrades, and software patching occurs, in the event they are requested or required

question: what should i do if my queries seem to be running slowly?
answer: for production databases we encourage you to enable enhanced monitoring, which provides access to over 50 cpu, memory, file system, and disk i/o metrics

question: how does amazon rds distinguish between “major” and “minor” db engine versions?
answer: refer to the faqs page for each amazon rds database engine for specifics on version numbering

question: does amazon rds provide guidelines for support of new db engine versions?
answer: over time, amazon rds adds support for new major and minor database engine versions

question: how do i specify which supported db engine version i would like my db instance to run?
answer: you can specify any currently supported version (major and minor) when creating a new db instance via the launch db instance operation in the aws management console or the createdbinstance api

question: how do i control if and when the engine version of my db instance is upgraded to new supported versions?
answer: amazon rds strives to keep your database instance up to date by providing you newer versions of the supported database engines

question: can i test my db instance with a new version before upgrading?
answer: yes, you can do so by creating a db snapshot of your existing db instance, restoring from the db snapshot to create a new db instance, and then initiating a version upgrade for the new db instance

question: does amazon rds provide guidelines for deprecating database engine versions that are currently supported?
answer: we intend to support major version releases (e

question: what happens when an rds db engine version is deprecated?
answer: when a minor version of a database engine is deprecated in amazon rds, we will provide a three (3) month period after the announcement before beginning automatic upgrades

question: when does billing of my amazon rds db instances begin and end?
answer: billing commences for a db instance as soon as the db instance is available

question: what defines billable amazon rds instance hours?
answer: db instance hours are billed for each hour your db instance is running in an available state

question: how will i be billed for a stopped db instance?
answer: while your database instance is stopped, you are charged for provisioned storage (including provisioned iops) and backup storage (including manual snapshots and automated backups within your specified retention window), but not for db instance hours

question: why does my additional backup storage cost more than allocated db instance storage?
answer: the storage provisioned to your db instance for your primary data is located within a single availability zone

question: for what time period will the aws free tier for amazon rds be available to me?
answer: new aws accounts receive 12 months of aws free tier access

question: can i run more than one db instance under the aws free usage tier for amazon rds?
answer: yes, you can run more than one single-az micro db instance simultaneously and be eligible for usage counted under the aws free tier for amazon rds

question: do i have access to 750 instance hours each of the mysql, mariadb, postgresql, oracle and sql server micro db instances under the aws free tier?
answer: no, a customer with access to the aws free tier can use up to 750 instance hours of micro instances running either mysql, postgresql, oracle or sql server express edition

question: how am i billed when my instance-hour usage exceeds the free tier benefit?
answer: you are billed at standard amazon rds prices for instance hours beyond what the free tier provides

question: what is a reserved instance (ri)?
answer: amazon rds reserved instances give you the option to reserve a db instance for a one or three year term and in turn receive a significant discount compared to the on-demand instance pricing for the db instance

question: how are reserved instances different from on-demand db instances?
answer: functionally, reserved instances and on-demand db instances are exactly the same

question: how do i purchase and create reserved instances?
answer: you can purchase a reserved instance in the "reserved instance" section of the aws management console for amazon rds

question: do reserved instances include a capacity reservation?
answer: amazon rds reserved instances are purchased for a region rather than for a specific availability zone

question: how many reserved instances can i purchase?
answer: you can purchase up to 40 reserved db instances

question: what if i have an existing db instance that i’d like to cover with a reserved instance?
answer: simply purchase a db instance reservation with the same db instance class, db engine, multi-az option and license model within the same region as the db instance you are currently running and would like to reserve

question: if i sign up for a reserved instance, when does the term begin? what happens to my db instance when the term ends?
answer: pricing changes associated with a reserved instance are activated once your request is received while the payment authorization is processed

question: how do i control which db instances are billed at the reserved instance rate?
answer: the amazon rds operations for creating, modifying, and deleting db instances do not distinguish between on-demand and reserved instances

question: can i move a reserved instance from one region or availability zone to another?
answer: each reserved instance is associated with a specific region, which is fixed for the lifetime of the reservation and cannot be changed

question: are reserved instances available for multi-az deployments?
answer: yes, when you purchase a reserved instance, you can select the multi-az option in the db instance configuration available for purchase

question: are reserved instances available for read replicas?
answer: a db instance reservation can be applied to a read replica, provided the db instance class and region are the same

question: can i cancel a reservation?
answer: no, you cannot cancel your reserved db instance and the one-time payment (if applicable) is not refundable

question: how do i determine which initial db instance class and storage capacity are appropriate for my needs?
answer: in order to select your initial db instance class and storage capacity, you will want to assess your application’s compute, memory and storage needs

question: how do i scale the compute resources and/or storage capacity associated with my amazon rds database instance?
answer: you can scale the compute resources and storage capacity allocated to your db instance with the aws management console (selecting the desired db instance and clicking the modify button), the rds api, or the aws command line interface

question: what is the hardware configuration for amazon rds storage?
answer: amazon rds uses ebs volumes for database and log storage

question: will my db instance remain available during scaling?
answer: the storage capacity allocated to your db instance can be increased while maintaining db instance availability

question: how can i scale my db instance beyond the largest db instance class and maximum storage capacity?
answer: amazon rds supports a variety of db instance classes and storage allocations to meet different application needs

question: what is amazon rds general purpose (ssd) storage?
answer: amazon rds general purpose (ssd) storage is suitable for a broad range of database workloads that have moderate i/o requirements

question: what is amazon rds provisioned iops (ssd) storage?
answer: amazon rds provisioned iops (ssd) storage is an ssd-backed storage option designed to deliver fast, predictable, and consistent i/o performance

question: what is amazon rds magnetic storage?
answer: amazon rds magnetic storage is useful for small database workloads where data is accessed less frequently

question: how do i choose among the amazon rds storage types?
answer: choose the storage type most suited for your workload

question: what are the minimum and maximum iops supported by amazon rds?
answer: the iops supported by amazon rds varies by database engine

question: what is the difference between automated backups and db snapshots?
answer: amazon rds provides two different methods for backing up and restoring your db instance(s) automated backups and database snapshots (db snapshots)

question: do i need to enable backups for my db instance or is it done automatically?
answer: by default, amazon rds enables automated backups of your db instance with a 7 day retention period

question: what is a backup window and why do i need it? is my database available during the backup window?
answer: the preferred backup window is the user-defined period of time during which your db instance is backed up

question: where are my automated backups and db snapshots stored and how do i manage their retention?
answer: amazon rds db snapshots and automated backups are stored in s3

question: why do i have more automated db snapshots than the number of days in the retention period for my db instance?
answer: it is normal to have 1 or 2 more automated db snapshots than the number of days in your retention period

question: what happens to my backups and db snapshots if i delete my db instance?
answer: when you delete a db instance, you can create a final db snapshot upon deletion; if you do, you can use this db snapshot to restore the deleted db instance at a later date

question: what is amazon virtual private cloud (vpc) and how does it work with amazon rds?
answer: amazon vpc lets you create a virtual networking environment in a private, isolated section of the aws cloud, where you can exercise complete control over aspects such as private ip address ranges, subnets, routing tables and network gateways

question: how is using amazon rds inside a vpc different from using it on the ec2-classic platform (non-vpc)?
answer: if your aws account was created before 2013-12-04, you may be able to run amazon rds in an amazon elastic compute cloud (ec2)-classic environment

question: what is a db subnet group and why do i need one?
answer: a db subnet group is a collection of subnets that you may want to designate for your rds db instances in a vpc

question: how do i create an amazon rds db instance in vpc?
answer: for a procedure that walks you through this process, refer to creating a db instance in a vpc in the amazon rds user guide

question: how do i control network access to my db instance(s)?
answer: visit the security groups section of the amazon rds user guide to learn about the different ways to control access to your db instances

question: how do i connect to an rds db instance in vpc?
answer: db instances deployed within a vpc can be accessed by ec2 instances deployed in the same vpc

question: can i move my existing db instances outside vpc into my vpc?
answer: if your db instance is not in a vpc, you can use the aws management console to easily move your db instance into a vpc

question: can i move my existing db instances from inside vpc to outside vpc?
answer: migration of db instances from inside to outside vpc is not supported

question: what precautions should i take to ensure that my db instances in vpc are accessible by my application?
answer: you are responsible for modifying routing tables and networking acls in your vpc to ensure that your db instance is reachable from your client instances in the vpc

question: can i change the db subnet group of my db instance?
answer: an existing db subnet group can be updated to add more subnets, either for existing availability zones or for new availability zones added since the creation of the db instance

question: what is an amazon rds master user account and how is it different from an aws account?
answer: to begin using amazon rds you will need an aws developer account

question: is there anything different about user management with amazon rds?
answer: no, everything works the way you are familiar with when using a relational database you manage yourself

question: can programs running on servers in my own data center access amazon rds databases?
answer: yes, you have to intentionally turn on the ability to access your database over the internet by configuring security groups

question: can i encrypt connections between my application and my db instance using ssl/tls?
answer: yes, this option is supported for all amazon rds engines

question: how do i control the actions that my systems and users can take on specific rds resources?
answer: you can control the actions that your aws iam users and groups can take on rds resources

question: can i use amazon rds with applications that require hipaa compliance?
answer: yes, all rds database engines are hipaa-eligible, so you can use them to build hipaa-compliant applications and store healthcare related information, including protected health information (phi) under an executed business associate agreement (baa) with aws if you already have an executed baa, no action is necessary to begin using these services in the account(s) covered by your baa

question: how do i choose the right configuration parameters for my db instance(s)?
answer: by default, amazon rds chooses the optimal configuration parameters for your db instance taking into account the instance class and storage capacity

question: what are db parameter groups? how are they helpful?
answer: a database parameter group (db parameter group) acts as a “container” for engine configuration values that can be applied to one or more db instances

question: how can i monitor the configuration of my amazon rds resources?
answer: you can use aws config to continuously record configurations changes to amazon rds db instances, db subnet groups, db snapshots, db security groups, and event subscriptions and receive notification of changes through amazon simple notification service (sns)

question: what does it mean to run a db instance as a multi-az deployment?
answer: when you create or modify your db instance to run as a multi-az deployment, amazon rds automatically provisions and maintains a synchronous “standby” replica in a different availability zone

question: what is an availability zone?
answer: availability zones are distinct locations within a region that are engineered to be isolated from failures in other availability zones

question: what do “primary” and “standby” mean in the context of a multi-az deployment?
answer: when you run a db instance as a multi-az deployment, the “primary” serves database writes and reads

question: what are the benefits of a multi-az deployment?
answer: the chief benefits of running your db instance as a multi-az deployment are enhanced database durability and availability

question: are there any performance implications of running my db instance as a multi-az deployment?
answer: you may observe elevated latencies relative to a standard db instance deployment in a single availability zone as a result of the synchronous data replication performed on your behalf

question: when running my db instance as a multi-az deployment, can i use the standby for read or write operations?
answer: no, a multi-az standby cannot serve read requests

question: how do i set up a multi-az db instance deployment?
answer: in order to create a multi-az db instance deployment, simply click the “yes” option for “multi-az deployment” when launching a db instance with the aws management console

question: will i be alerted when automatic failover occurs?
answer: yes, amazon rds will emit a db instance event to inform you that automatic failover occurred

question: what happens during multi-az failover and how long does it take?
answer: failover is automatically handled by amazon rds so that you can resume database operations as quickly as possible without administrative intervention

question: can i initiate a “forced failover” for my multi-az db instance deployment?
answer: amazon rds will automatically fail over without user intervention under a variety of failure conditions

question: how do i control/configure multi-az synchronous replication?
answer: with multi-az deployments, you simply set the “multi-az” parameter to true

question: will my standby be in the same region as my primary?
answer: yes, your standby is automatically provisioned in a different availability zone of the same region as your db instance primary

question: can i see which availability zone my primary is currently located in?
answer: yes, you can gain visibility into the location of the current primary by using the aws management console or describedbinstances api

question: after failover, my primary is now located in a different availability zone than my other aws resources (e.g. ec2 instances). should i be concerned about latency?
answer: availability zones are engineered to provide low latency network connectivity to other availability zones in the same region

question: how do db snapshots and automated backups work with my multi-az deployment?
answer: you interact with automated backup and db snapshot functionality in the same way whether you are running a standard deployment in a single-az or multi-az deployment

question: what does it mean to run a db instance as a read replica?
answer: read replicas make it easy to take advantage of supported engines' built-in replication functionality to elastically scale out beyond the capacity constraints of a single db instance for read-heavy database workloads

question: do i need to enable automatic backups on my db instance before i can create read replicas?
answer: yes, enable automatic backups on your source db instance before adding read replicas, by setting the backup retention period to a value other than 0

question: which versions of database engines support amazon rds read replicas?
answer: amazon auror all db clusters

question: how do i deploy a read replica for a given db instance?
answer: you can create a read replica in minutes using the standard createdbinstancereadreplica api or a few clicks on the aws management console

question: how do i connect to my read replica(s)?
answer: you can connect to a read replica just as you would connect to a standard db instance, using the describedbinstance api or aws management console to retrieve the endpoint(s) for you read replica(s)

question: how many read replicas can i create for a given source db instance?
answer: amazon rds for mysql, mariadb, postgresql, oracle and sql server allow you to create up to 5 read replicas for a given source db instance

question: can i create a read replica in an aws region different from that of the source db instance?
answer: yes, amazon rds (except rds for sql server) supports cross-region read replicas

question: do amazon rds read replicas support synchronous replication?
answer: no, read replicas in amazon rds for mysql, mariadb, postgresql, oracle and sql server are implemented using those engines' native asynchronous replication

question: can i use a read replica to enhance database write availability or protect the data on my source db instance against failure scenarios?
answer: if you are looking to use replication to increase database write availability and protect recent database updates against various failure conditions, we recommend you run your db instance as a multi-az deployment

question: can i create a read replica with a multi-az db instance deployment as its source?
answer: yes, since multi-az db instances address a different need than read replicas, it makes sense to use the two in conjunction for production deployments and to associate a read replica with a multi-az db instance deployment

question: can i configure my amazon rds read replicas themselves multi-az?
answer: yes, amazon rds for mysql, mariadb, postgresql, and oracle allow you to enable multi-az configuration on read replicas to support disaster recovery and minimize downtime from engine upgrades

question: if my read replica(s) use a multi-az db instance deployment as a source, what happens if multi-az failover occurs?
answer: in the event of multi-az failover, any associated and available read replicas will automatically resume replication once failover has completed (acquiring updates from the newly promoted primary)

question: can my read replicas only accept database read operations?
answer: read replicas are designed to serve read traffic

question: can i promote my read replica into a “standalone” db instance?
answer: yes, refer to the amazon rds user guide for more details

question: how do i see the status of my active read replica(s)?
answer: you can use the standard describedbinstances api to return a list of all the db instances you have deployed (including read replicas), or simply click on the "instances" tab of the amazon rds console

question: i scaled the compute and/or storage capacity of my source db instance. should i scale the resources for associated read replica(s) as well?
answer: for replication to work effectively, we recommend that read replicas have as much or more compute and storage resources as their respective source db instances

question: how do i delete a read replica? will it be deleted automatically if its source db instance is deleted?
answer: you can easily delete a read replica with a few clicks of the aws management console or by passing its db instance identifier to the deletedbinstance api

question: how much do read replicas cost? when does billing begin and end?
answer: a read replica is billed as a standard db instance and at the same rates

question: what is enhanced monitoring for rds?
answer: enhanced monitoring for rds gives you deeper visibility into the health of your rds instances

question: which metrics and processes can i monitor in enhanced monitoring?
answer: enhanced monitoring captures your rds instance system level metrics such as the cpu, memory, file system and disk i/o among others

question: which engines are supported by enhanced monitoring?
answer: enhanced monitoring supports all rds database engines

question: which instance types are supported by enhanced monitoring?
answer: enhanced monitoring supports every instance type except t1

question: what information can i view on the rds dashboard?
answer: you can view all the system metrics and process information for your rds db instances in a graphical format on the console

question: will all the instances in my rds account sample metrics at the same granularity?
answer: no, you can set different granularities for each db instance in your rds account

question: how far back can i see the historical metrics on the rds console?
answer: you can see the performance values for all the metrics up to 1 hour back, at a granularity of up to 1 second, based on your settings

question: how can i visualize the metrics generated by rds enhanced monitoring in cloudwatch?
answer: the metrics from rds enhanced monitoring are delivered into your cloudwatch logs account

question: when should i use cloudwatch instead of the rds console dashboard?
answer: you should use cloudwatch if you want to view historical data beyond what is available on the rds console dashboard

question: can i set up alarms and notifications based on specific metrics?
answer: yes, you can create an alarm in cloudwatch that sends a notification when the alarm changes state

question: how do i integrate enhanced monitoring with my tool that i currently use?
answer: rds enhanced monitoring provides a set of metrics formed as json payloads which are delivered into your cloudwatch logs account

question: how can i delete historical data?
answer: since enhanced monitoring delivers json payloads into a log in your cloudwatch logs account, you can control its retention period just like any other cloudwatch logs stream

question: what impact does enhanced monitoring have on my monthly bills?
answer: since the metrics are ingested into cloudwatch logs, your charges will be based on cloudwatch logs data transfer and storage rates once you exceed cloudwatch logs free tier

question: what is amazon rds proxy?
answer: amazon rds proxy is a fully managed, highly available database proxy feature for amazon rds

question: how will serverless applications benefit from amazon rds proxy?
answer: amazon rds proxy transforms your approach to building modern serverless applications that leverage the power and simplicity of relational databases

question: which database engines does amazon rds proxy support?
answer: the amazon rds proxy preview is available for amazon aurora with mysql compatibility and amazon rds for mysql

question: how can i enable amazon rds proxy?
answer: you enable amazon rds proxy for your rds database with just a few clicks in the rds console

question: what is amazon quicksight?
answer: amazon quicksight is a very fast, easy-to-use, cloud-powered business analytics service that makes it easy for all employees within an organization to build visualizations, perform ad-hoc analysis, and quickly get business insights from their data, anytime, on any device

question: how is amazon quicksight different from traditional business intelligence (bi) solutions?
answer: traditional bi solutions often require teams of data engineers to spend months building complex data models before generating a report

question: how can i get started with amazon quicksight?
answer: to get started, sign up to amazon quicksight, with 4 authors free in trial for 30 days

question: what does up to $5/mo. on reader charges mean?
answer: a reader will be charged $0

question: can i use amazon quicksight on my mobile device?
answer: quicksight mobile apps (available on ios and android) gives instant access to your data and insights for you to make decisions on the go

question: on which browsers is amazon quicksight supported?
answer: amazon quicksight supports the latest versions of mozilla firefox, chrome, safari, internet explorer version 10 and above and edge

question: which data sources does amazon quicksight support?
answer: you can connect to aws data sources including amazon rds, amazon aurora, amazon redshift, amazon athena and amazon s3

question: can i connect amazon quicksight to my amazon ec2 or on-premises database?
answer: yes, in order to connect amazon quicksight to an amazon ec2 or on-premises database, you need to add the amazon quicksight ip range to the authorized list in your hosted database

question: how do i upload my data files into amazon quicksight?
answer: you can upload xlsx, csv, tsv, clf, xlf data files directly from amazon quicksight website

question: how do i access my data in aws data sources?
answer: amazon quicksight seamlessly discovers your aws data sources that are available in your account with your approval

question: my source data is not in a clean format. how do i format and transform the data before visualizing?

question: what is amazon transcribe?

question: does amazon transcribe support real-time transcriptions?

question: what encoding does real-time transcription support?

question: what languages does amazon transcribe support?

question: what programming languages does amazon transcribe support?

question: my custom vocabulary words are not being recognized! what can i do?
answer: the speech recognition output depends on a number of factors in addition to custom vocabulary entries, so there can be no assurance that if a term is included in the custom vocabulary, it will be correctly recognized

question: why do i see too many custom words in my output?
answer: custom vocabularies are optimized for a small list of targeted words; larger vocabularies may lead to over-generation of custom words, especially when they contain words that are pronounced in a similar way

question: there are two ways of giving pronunciations, ipa or soundslike fields in the custom vocabulary table. which one is better?
answer: ipa allows for more precise pronunciations

question: i'd like to use ipa but i'm not a linguistic expert. is there an online tool i can use?

question: do i need to use different ipa standards that are specific to a different accents of the same language? (e.g. us english versus british english)?
answer: you should use the ipa standard that is appropriate for the audio files you will be processing — e

question: how can i provide the pronunciation using soundslike field in the custom vocabulary table?
answer: you can break a word or phrase down into smaller pieces and provide a pronunciation for each piece using the standard orthography of the language to mimic the way that the word sounds

question: how do two different ways of providing acronyms (with periods and without periods but with pronunciations) work?
answer: if you use an acronym containing periods, the spelling pronunciation will be generated internally

question: what happens if i use the wrong ipa? if i am uncertain, am i better off not inputting any ipa?

question: what else should i know before using automatic content redaction?

question: which apis support automatic language identification?

question: what languages can amazon transcribe automatically identify?

question: what is aws migration hub?
answer: aws migration hub provides access to the tools you need to collect and inventory your existing it assets based on actual usage, analyze application components and infrastructure dependencies, and group resources into applications

question: why should i use aws migration hub?
answer: aws migration hub is the one destination for cloud migration and modernization, giving you the tools you need to accelerate and simplify your journey with aws if you’re making the case for cloud within your organization; planning, executing, and tracking a portfolio of applications migrating to aws; or modernizing applications currently running on aws, migration hub can help with your cloud transformation journey

question: what migration tools integrate with aws migration hub?
answer: aws application migration service, aws server migration service, aws database migration service, and atadata atamotion are integrated with aws migration hub and automatically report migration status to migration hub

question: how does aws migration hub help me track the progress of my application migrations?
answer: aws migration hub helps you by providing visibility into your migration progress

question: how does aws migration hub help me understand my it environment?

question: how much does it cost to use aws migration hub?
answer: aws migration hub is available to all aws customers at no additional charge

question: how do i get started with aws migration hub?
answer: follow the getting started guide in our documentation to get started

question: what regions can i migrate to using aws migration hub?
answer: aws migration hub helps you track the status of your migrations in all aws regions, provided your migration tools are available in that region

question: where is aws migration hub available?
answer: aws migration hub is available worldwide for tracking the progress of application migrations, regardless of where the application currently resides

question: how is access granted to aws migration hub?
answer: aws migration hub requires an aws account role, which will be added automatically the first time you access the console as an admin user

question: how do i view my it portfolio in aws migration hub?
answer: to view your it assets in aws migration hub, first you perform discovery using an aws discovery tool or by migrating with an integrated migration tool

question: how do i add resources into the discovery repository?
answer: when you first visit aws migration hub, you’re prompted to perform discovery or start migrating

question: how do i group servers into an application?
answer: before grouping servers into an application, you need to populate aws migration hub’s servers list

question: how do i view applications?
answer: you can visit the applications page in the migrate section of the aws migration hub console to see the list of applications and their current migration status

question: can i see applications created by other users within the same account?
answer: yes, applications created by any iam user within an account will be visible to any other iam users within the same account that are granted access to aws migration hub

question: can i see applications that exist in other aws accounts?
answer: you access aws migration hub using an iam user associated with an aws account

question: how does the aws migration hub import feature work?
answer: you can access the aws migration hub import feature either from the migration hub console or by invoking the application discovery service apis

question: what kind of data can i import using the import template?
answer: migration hub import allows you to import server details, including server specifications, utilization, tags and applications that are associated with your servers

question: is there a limit on the number of import files that i can upload?
answer: no, there is no limit on the number of import files that you can upload

question: i don't have data for all the fields in the import template. can i still import my data?
answer: yes, you can import data even if you don’t have data populated for all the fields in the import template

question: what are the criteria for identifying an incorrect record?
answer: import does a data validation check for all the imported fields that are part of the csv import template

question: what is the ec2 instance recommendations feature?
answer: ec2 instance recommendations is a feature of aws migration hub that analyzes the data collected from each on-premises server, including server specification, cpu, and memory utilization, to recommend the least expensive ec2 instance required to run the on-premises workload

question: how does the ec2 instance recommendations feature provide a match for a given server?
answer: the ec2 instance recommendations feature recommends the most cost-effective ec2 instance type that can satisfy the given cpu and ram requirements while taking into account your selected instance type preferences such as aws purchasing option, aws region, ec2 instance type exclusions, and cpu/ram utilization metric (average, peak, or percentile)

question: does the ec2 instance recommendations feature provide recommendations for burstable performance instances?
answer: yes, the ec2 instance recommendations feature provides recommendations for burstable performance instances

question: what happens if i have discovery data from multiple sources for the same server in aws migration hub? which data source is used to calculate the ec2 instance recommendation for that server?
answer: if discovery data is available from multiple sources for the same server, the ec2 instance recommendations feature will use the most recent and complete data to provide an instance recommendation

question: does the ec2 instance recommendations feature recommend current generation instances?
answer: yes, the ec2 instance recommendations feature only recommends current generation instances

question: when should i use the ec2 instance recommendations feature in aws migration hub compared to a more detailed cost assessment with tso logic?
answer: right-sizing your compute resources is one dimension of understanding your total cost of ownership (tco)

question: how do i use aws migration hub when migrating applications?
answer: after you’ve created one or more application groupings from servers discovered using aws discovery tools or by starting to migrate using an integrated migration tool, you can start or continue to migrate the server or database outside migration hub

question: does aws migration hub automatically migrate my applications for me?
answer: no, aws migration hub does not automate the steps of the migration

question: what do i need to do in order for my application’s migration progress to appear in aws migration hub?
answer: to view migration progress in aws migration hub, two things must be true

question: what is the experience if i don’t do a strict re-host migration, moving the resources exactly from on-premises to aws?

question: how can other tools publish status to aws migration hub?
answer: migration tools can publish your status to aws migration hub by writing to the aws migration hub api

question: what is strategy recommendations?
answer: aws migration hub’s strategy recommendations helps you easily build a migration and modernization strategy for your applications running on premises or in aws strategy recommendations provides guidance on the strategy and tools that help you migrate and modernize at scale

question: what migration and modernization options does strategy recommendations support?
answer: strategy recommendations supports analysis for potential rehost (ec2) and replatform (managed environments such as rds and elastic beanstalk, containers, and os upgrades) options for applications running on windows server 2003 or above or a wide variety of linux distributions, including ubuntu, redhat, oracle linux, debian, and fedora

question: what additional options do i have to modernize my windows workloads?
answer: please visit modernize windows workloads with aws to know more

question: what is amazon virtual private cloud?
answer: amazon vpc lets you provision a logically isolated section of the amazon web services (aws) cloud where you can launch aws resources in a virtual network that you define

question: how will i be charged and billed for my use of amazon vpc?
answer: there are no additional charges for creating and using the vpc itself

question: what usage charges will i incur if i use other aws services, such as amazon s3, from amazon ec2 instances in my vpc?
answer: usage charges for other amazon web services, including amazon ec2, still apply at published rates for those resources

question: what ip address ranges can i use within my amazon vpc?
answer: you can use any ipv4 address range, including rfc 1918 or publicly routable ip ranges, for the primary cidr block

question: how do i assign ip address ranges to amazon vpcs?
answer: you assign a single classless internet domain routing (cidr) ip address range as the primary cidr block when you create a vpc and can add up to four (4) secondary cidr blocks after creation of the vpc

question: what ip address ranges are assigned to a default amazon vpc?
answer: default vpcs are assigned a cidr range of 172

question: can i advertise my vpc public ip address range to the internet and route the traffic through my datacenter, via the aws site-to-site vpn, and to my amazon vpc?
answer: yes, you can route traffic via the aws site-to-site vpn connection and advertise the address range from your home network

question: how large of a vpc can i create?
answer: currently, amazon vpc supports five (5) ip address ranges, one (1) primary and four (4) secondary for ipv4

question: can i change the size of a vpc?
answer: yes, you can expand your existing vpc by adding four (4) secondary ipv4 ip ranges (cidrs) to your vpc

question: how many subnets can i create per vpc?
answer: currently you can create 200 subnets per vpc

question: is there a limit on how large or small a subnet can be?
answer: the minimum size of a subnet is a /28 (or 14 ip addresses

question: can i use all the ip addresses that i assign to a subnet?
answer: no, amazon reserves the first four (4) ip addresses and the last one (1) ip address of every subnet for ip networking purposes

question: how do i assign private ip addresses to amazon ec2 instances within a vpc?
answer: when you launch an amazon ec2 instance within a subnet that is not ipv6-only, you may optionally specify the primary private ipv4 address for the instance

question: can i change the private ip addresses of an amazon ec2 instance while it is running and/or stopped within a vpc?
answer: for an instance launched in an ipv4 or dual-stack subnet, the primary private ipv4 address is retained for the instance's or interface's lifetime

question: can i assign ip addresses for multiple instances simultaneously?
answer: no, you can specify the ip address of one instance at a time when launching the instance

question: can i assign multiple ip addresses to an instance?
answer: yes, you can assign one or more secondary private ip addresses to an elastic network interface or an ec2 instance in amazon vpc

question: can i assign one or more elastic ip (eip) addresses to vpc-based amazon ec2 instances?
answer: yes, however, the eip addresses will only be reachable from the internet (not over the vpn connection)

question: can i specify which subnet will use which gateway as its default?
answer: yes, you may create a default route for each subnet

question: how do i secure amazon ec2 instances running within my vpc?
answer: amazon ec2 security groups can be used to help secure instances within an amazon vpc

question: what are the differences between security groups in a vpc and network acls in a vpc?
answer: security groups in a vpc specify which traffic is allowed to or from an amazon ec2 instance

question: what is the difference between stateful and stateless filtering?
answer: stateful filtering tracks the origin of a request and can automatically allow the reply to the request to be returned to the originating computer

question: can amazon ec2 instances within a vpc communicate with amazon ec2 instances not within a vpc?
answer: yes, if an internet gateway has been configured, amazon vpc traffic bound for amazon ec2 instances not within a vpc traverses the internet gateway and then enters the public aws network to reach the ec2 instance

question: can amazon ec2 instances within a vpc in one region communicate with amazon ec2 instances within a vpc in another region?
answer: yes, instances in one region can communicate with each other using inter-region vpc peering, public ip addresses, nat gateway, nat instances, vpn connections or direct connect connections

question: can amazon ec2 instances within a vpc communicate with amazon s3?
answer: yes, there are multiple options for your resources within a vpc to communicate with amazon s3

question: can i monitor the network traffic in my vpc?
answer: yes, you can use amazon vpc traffic mirroring and amazon vpc flow logs features to monitor the network traffic in your amazon vpc

question: what is amazon vpc flow logs?
answer: vpc flow logs is a feature that enables you to capture information about the ip traffic going to and from network interfaces in your vpc

question: how can i use vpc flow logs?
answer: you can create a flow log for a vpc, a subnet, or a network interface

question: does using flow logs impact my network latency or performance?
answer: flow log data is collected outside of the path of your network traffic, and therefore does not affect network throughput or latency

question: how much vpc flow logs cost?
answer: data ingestion and archival charges for vended logs apply when you publish flow logs to cloudwatch logs or to amazon s3

question: what is amazon vpc traffic mirroring?
answer: amazon vpc traffic mirroring makes it easy for customers to replicate network traffic to and from an amazon ec2 instance and forward it to out-of-band security and monitoring appliances for use-cases such as content inspection, threat monitoring, and troubleshooting

question: how does amazon vpc traffic mirroring work?
answer: the traffic mirroring feature copies network traffic from elastic network interface (eni) of ec2 instances in your amazon vpc

question: which resources can be monitored with amazon vpc traffic mirroring ?
answer: traffic mirroring supports network packet captures at the elastic network interface (eni) level for ec2 instances

question: what type of appliances are supported with amazon vpc traffic mirroring?
answer: customers can either use open source tools or choose from a wide-range of monitoring solution available on aws marketplace

question: how is amazon vpc traffic mirroring different from amazon vpc flow logs?
answer: amazon vpc flow logs allow customers to collect, store, and analyze network flow logs

question: within which amazon ec2 region(s) is amazon vpc available?
answer: amazon vpc is currently available in multiple availability zones in all amazon ec2 regions

question: can a subnet span availability zones?
answer: no, a subnet must reside within a single availability zone

question: how do i specify which availability zone my amazon ec2 instances are launched in?
answer: when you launch an amazon ec2 instance, you must specify the subnet in which to launch the instance

question: how do i determine which availability zone my subnets are located in?
answer: when you create a subnet you must specify the availability zone in which to place the subnet

question: am i charged for network bandwidth between instances in different subnets?
answer: if the instances reside in subnets in different availability zones, you will be charged $0

question: when i call describeinstances(), do i see all of my amazon ec2 instances, including those in ec2-classic and ec2-vpc?
answer: yes, describeinstances() will return all running amazon ec2 instances

question: when i call describevolumes(), do i see all of my amazon ebs volumes, including those in ec2-classic and ec2-vpc?
answer: yes, describevolumes() will return all your ebs volumes

question: how many amazon ec2 instances can i use within a vpc?
answer: for instances that require ipv4 addressing, you can run any number of amazon ec2 instances within a vpc, so long as your vpc is appropriately sized to have an ipv4 address assigned to each instance

question: can i use my existing amis in amazon vpc?
answer: you can use amis in amazon vpc that are registered within the same region as your vpc

question: can i use my existing amazon ebs snapshots?
answer: yes, you may use amazon ebs snapshots if they are located in the same region as your vpc

question: can i boot an amazon ec2 instance from an amazon ebs volume within amazon vpc?
answer: yes, however, an instance launched in a vpc using an amazon ebs-backed ami maintains the same ip address when stopped and restarted

question: can i use amazon ec2 reserved instances with amazon vpc?
answer: yes, you can reserve an instance in amazon vpc when you purchase reserved instances

question: can i launch amazon ec2 cluster instances in a vpc?
answer: yes, cluster instances are supported in amazon vpc, however, not all instance types are available in all regions and availability zones

question: what are instance hostnames?
answer: when you launch an instance, it is assigned a hostname

question: can i change the instance hostname of my amazon ec2 instance?
answer: yes, you can change the hostname of an instance form ip based to resource based or vice versa by stopping the instance and then changing the resource based naming options

question: can i use the instance hostnames as dns hostnames?
answer: yes, the instance hostname can be used as dns hostnames

question: what is a default vpc?
answer: a default vpc is a logically isolated virtual network in the aws cloud that is automatically created for your aws account the first time you provision amazon ec2 resources

question: what are the benefits of a default vpc?
answer: when you launch resources in a default vpc, you can benefit from the advanced networking functionalities of amazon vpc (ec2-vpc) with the ease of use of amazon ec2 (ec2-classic)

question: what accounts are enabled for default vpc?
answer: if your aws account was created after march 18, 2013 your account may be able to launch resources in a default vpc

question: how can i tell if my account is configured to use a default vpc?
answer: the amazon ec2 console indicates which platforms you can launch instances in for the selected region, and whether you have a default vpc in that region

question: will i need to know anything about amazon vpc in order to use a default vpc?
answer: no, you can use the aws management console, aws ec2 cli, or the amazon ec2 api to launch and manage ec2 instances and other aws resources in a default vpc

question: what are the differences between instances launched in ec2-classic and ec2-vpc?
answer: see differences between ec2-classic and ec2-vpc in the ec2 user guide

question: do i need to have a vpn connection to use a default vpc?
answer: no, default vpcs are attached to the internet and all instances launched in default subnets in the default vpc automatically receive public ip addresses

question: can i create other vpcs and use them in addition to my default vpc?
answer: yes, to launch an instance into nondefault vpcs you must specify a subnet-id during instance launch

question: can i create additional subnets in my default vpc, such as private subnets?
answer: yes, to launch into nondefault subnets, you can target your launches using the console or the --subnet option from the cli, api, or sdk

question: how many default vpcs can i have?
answer: you can have one default vpc in each aws region where your supported platforms attribute is set to "ec2-vpc"

question: what is the ip range of a default vpc?
answer: the default vpc cidr is 172

question: how many default subnets are in a default vpc?
answer: one default subnet is created for each availability zone in your default vpc

question: can i specify which vpc is my default vpc?
answer: not at this time

question: can i delete a default vpc?
answer: yes, you can delete a default vpc

question: can i delete a default subnet?
answer: yes, you can delete a default subnet

question: i have an existing ec2-classic account. can i get a default vpc?
answer: the simplest way to get a default vpc is to create a new account in a region that is enabled for default vpcs, or use an existing account in a region you've never been to before, as long as the supported platforms attribute for that account in that region is set to "ec2-vpc"

question: i really want a default vpc for my existing ec2 account. is that possible?
answer: yes, however, we can only enable an existing account for a default vpc if you have no ec2-classic resources for that account in that region

question: how are iam accounts impacted by default vpc?
answer: if your aws account has a default vpc, any iam accounts associated with your aws account use the same default vpc as your aws account

question: what’s changing?

question: how is my account impacted by the retirement of ec2-classic?

question: can i have more than two network interfaces attached to my ec2 instance?
answer: the total number of network interfaces that can be attached to an ec2 instance depends on the instance type

question: can i attach a network interface in one availability zone to an instance in another availability zone?
answer: network interfaces can only be attached to instances residing in the same availability zone

question: can i attach a network interface in one vpc to an instance in another vpc?
answer: network interfaces can only be attached to instances in the same vpc as the interface

question: can i use elastic network interfaces as a way to host multiple websites requiring separate ip addresses on a single instance?
answer: yes, however, this is not a use case best suited for multiple interfaces

question: can i detach the primary interface (eth0) on my ec2 instance?
answer: no, you can attach and detach secondary interfaces (eth1-ethn) on an ec2 instance, but you can’t detach the eth0 interface

question: can i create a peering connection to a vpc in a different region?
answer: yes, peering connections can be created with vpcs in different regions

question: can i peer my vpc with a vpc belonging to another aws account?
answer: yes, assuming the owner of the other vpc accepts your peering connection request

question: can i peer two vpcs with matching ip address ranges?
answer: no, peered vpcs must have non-overlapping ip ranges

question: how much do vpc peering connections cost?
answer: there is no charge for creating vpc peering connections, however, data transfer across peering connections is charged

question: can i use aws direct connect or hardware vpn connections to access vpcs i’m peered with?
answer: no, “edge to edge routing” isn’t supported in amazon vpc

question: do i need an internet gateway to use peering connections?
answer: no, vpc peering connections do not require an internet gateway

question: is vpc peering traffic within the region encrypted?
answer: no, traffic between instances in peered vpcs remains private and isolated – similar to how traffic between two instances in the same vpc is private and isolated

question: if i delete my side of a peering connection, will the other side still have access to my vpc?
answer: no, either side of the peering connection can terminate the peering connection at any time

question: if i peer vpc a to vpc b and i peer vpc b to vpc c, does that mean vpcs a and c are peered?
answer: no, transitive peering relationships are not supported

question: what if my peering connection goes down?
answer: aws uses the existing infrastructure of a vpc to create a vpc peering connection; it is neither a gateway nor a vpn connection, and does not rely on a separate piece of physical hardware

question: are there any bandwidth limitations for peering connections?
answer: bandwidth between instances in peered vpcs is no different than bandwidth between instances in the same vpc

question: is inter-region vpc peering traffic encrypted?
answer: traffic is encrypted using modern aead (authenticated encryption with associated data) algorithms

question: how do dns translations work with inter-region vpc peering?

question: can i reference security groups across an inter-region vpc peering connection?
answer: no, security groups cannot be referenced across an inter-region vpc peering connection

question: does workspaces work with aws identity and access management (iam)?

question: can i select the organizational unit (ou) where computer accounts for my workspaces will be created in my active directory?

question: can i use amazon vpc security groups to limit access to resources (applications, databases) in my network or on the internet from my workspaces?
answer: yes, you can use amazon vpc security groups to limit access to resources in your network or the internet from your workspaces

question: what is an ip access control group?
answer: an ip access control group is a feature that lets you specify trusted ip addresses that are permitted to access your workspaces

question: can i implement ip address-based access controls for workspaces?

question: how can i implement ip address-based access controls?

question: can ip address-based access controls be used with all workspaces clients?

question: which zero client configurations are compatible with the ip based access controls feature?

question: are there any scenarios where a non-whitelisted ip address could access a workspace?

question: how are ip addresses whitelisted if users are accessing the workspaces through a network address translation (nat)?

question: how should ip addresses be whitelisted for vpns?

question: how do i enable uri?

question: does amazon workspaces support encryption?

question: which amazon workspaces bundle types support encryption?
answer: encryption is supported on all amazon workspaces hardware and software bundle types

question: how can i encrypt a new amazon workspace?

question: can amazon workspaces create a kms key on my behalf?
answer: amazon workspaces creates a default master key upon your first attempt to launch a workspace through the aws management console

question: what are the prerequisites for using kms keys to encrypt amazon workspaces?
answer: in order to use kms keys to encrypt amazon workspaces, the key must not be disabled, and should not have exceeded its limits (learn more about limits here)

question: how will i be notified if my kms key does not meet the pre-requisites outlined above?
answer: when you launch a new workspace with the key specified, the workspaces service will verify if the key is valid and eligible to be used for encryption

question: how will i be able to tell which amazon workspaces are encrypted and which ones are not?
answer: you will be able to see if a workspace is encrypted or not from the aws management console or using the amazon workspaces api

question: can i enable encryption of volumes on a running amazon workspace?
answer: encryption of workspaces is only supported during the creation and launch of a workspace

question: what happens to a running amazon workspace when i disable the key in the kms console?
answer: a running workspace will not be impacted if you disable the kms key that was used to encrypt the user volume of the workspace

question: is it possible to disable encryption for a running amazon workspace?
answer: amazon workspaces does not support disabling encryption for a running workspace

question: will snapshots of an encrypted user volume also be encrypted?
answer: yes, all snapshots of the user volume will be encrypted using the same key that was used to encrypt the user volume of the workspace when it was created

question: can i rebuild an amazon workspace that has been encrypted?
answer: yes, rebuilds of a workspace will work as long as the key that was used to encrypt the workspace is still valid

question: can i restore an amazon workspace that has been encrypted?
answer: yes, a workspace restore will work as long as the key that was used to encrypt the workspace is still valid

question: can i create a custom image from a workspace that has been encrypted?
answer: creating a custom image from a workspace that is encrypted is not supported

question: will the performance of my workspace be impacted because the volume(s) are encrypted?
answer: you can expect a minimum increase in latency on iops on encrypted volumes

question: will encryption impact the launch time of an amazon workspace?
answer: the launch time of a workspace that only requires user volume encryption are similar to those of an unencrypted workspace

question: will encryption be supported for byol workspaces?
answer: yes, amazon workspaces will support encryption for byol workspaces

question: will i be able to use the same kms key to encrypt amazon workspaces in a different region?
answer: no, encrypted resources in one region cannot be used in a different region, because a kms key belongs to the region in which it was created

question: is there a charge for encrypting volumes on amazon workspaces?
answer: there is no additional charge for encrypting volumes on workspaces, however you will have to pay standard aws kms charges for kms api requests and any custom cmks that are used to encrypt workspaces

question: can i rotate my kms keys?
answer: yes, you can use kms to rotate your custom cmks

question: what is amazon workspaces application manager?

question: how are amazon wam applications delivered to users?

question: what type of applications can be delivered using amazon wam?

question: can i track application use with amazon wam?
answer: you can track usage for any applications assigned to users

question: in which aws regions is amazon wam available?

question: which amazon workspaces experiences work with amazon wam?

question: which aws directory service directories does amazon wam support?
answer: amazon wam can be used with aws directory services ad connector and simple ad, or aws managed microsoft ad

question: do amazon workspaces need internet access to use amazon wam?

question: how do i get amazon wam on my users’ amazon workspaces?

question: how do end users access applications that are assigned using amazon wam?

question: how many applications can i add to my amazon wam catalog?
answer: there is no limit to the number of applications you can add to your amazon wam catalog

question: how many applications can i deliver to each amazon workspaces user via amazon wam?
answer: you can assign up to 50 applications to each amazon workspaces user

question: can i use tags to categorize applications in my amazon wam catalogs?

question: how will i be billed for amazon wam?

question: can i have users on both the lite and the standard plans?

question: what will happen to my applications if i downgrade from the standard to the lite plan?
answer: users will be moved to the most up to date version of applications from aws marketplace for desktop apps, and will lose access to any applications that you packaged and uploaded to amazon wam

question: is there a limit for storage of my app packages?

question: can i share an amazon wam package with another aws account?

question: can i set limits on the packages that i share with other aws accounts?

question: how do i know if i can trust a package that has been shared with my account?
answer: always verify that your package is shared from a trusted source

question: can i delete an amazon wam package?

question: what happens to an amazon wam package once it is deleted?

question: how do i use desktop applications from aws marketplace?

question: how will i be charged for applications from the aws marketplace for desktop apps?

question: how do i unsubscribe from an application?

question: how do i get support for the applications i use from aws marketplace for desktop apps?

question: can i use any other client (e.g., an rdp client) with amazon workspaces?

question: how can i determine the best region to run my amazon workspaces?

question: how do i manage my workspaces?

question: can i use tags to categorize my amazon workspaces resources?

question: how do i remove an amazon workspace i no longer require?

question: can i provide more than one amazon workspace per user?

question: how many amazon workspaces can i launch?

answer: the bandwidth needed to use your workspace depends on what you're doing on your workspace

question: is there a recommended power plan or power settings for my workspaces?

question: does workspaces need any quality of service configurations to be updated on my network?

question: is mfa on amazon workspaces available in my region?

question: how do i get support with amazon workspaces?

question: how does billing work for amazon workspaces?

question: how will i be charged for amazon workspaces that i launch that are based on a custom image?

question: are there any costs associated with tagging amazon workspaces?

question: can i pay for amazon wam on an hourly basis?

question: do i have to pay to use the amazon wam studio or amazon wam player?

question: what are the requirements for schools, universities, and public institutions to reduce their workspaces licensing?

question: does qualification for amazon workspaces reduced user fees affect other aws cloud services?
answer: no, your user fees are specific to amazon workspaces, and do not affect any other aws cloud services or licenses you have

question: is there a charge for streaming data between my workspaces and end users' devices?

question: am i eligible to take advantage of the amazon workspaces free tier offer?

question: what amazon workspaces bundles are available as part of the free tier?

question: what is included with the amazon workspaces free tier?

question: can i use any other amazon workspaces bundles as part of the free tier?

question: hourly billing for amazon workspaces includes a fee for hours used, and a monthly infrastructure cost. is the monthly infrastructure cost waived during the amazon workspaces free tier?

question: can i connect amazon workspaces to my vpc?

question: can i connect to my existing active directory with my amazon workspaces?

question: what are the pre-requisites for using my digital certificates on amazon workspaces?

question: what are the pre-requisites for enabling mfa on amazon workspaces?

question: do i need to set up a directory to use the amazon workspaces service?

question: there are two options for integrating amazon workspaces with my on-premises microsoft active directory. which one should i use?

question: what are vcpu-based limits?

question: what are some of the ideal use cases for r6g instances?
answer: r6g instances deliver significant price performance benefits for memory-intensive workloads such as instances and are ideal for running memory-intensive workloads such as open-source databases, in-memory caches, and real time big data analytics

question: what are the various storage options available on r6g instances?
answer: r6g instances are ebs-optimized by default and offer up to 19,000 mbps of dedicated ebs bandwidth to both encrypted and unencrypted ebs volumes

question: which network interface is supported on r6g instances?
answer: r6g instances support ena based enhanced networking

question: why should customers choose r6i instances over r5 instances?
answer: amazon r6i instances are powered by 3rd generation intel xeon scalable processors (code named ice lake) with an all-core turbo frequency of 3

question: what are amazon ec2 r5b instances?
answer: r5b instances are ebs-optimized variants of memory-optimized r5 instances that deliver up to 3x better ebs performance compared to same sized r5 instances

question: what are some of the ideal use cases for r5b instances?
answer: r5b instances are ideal for large relational database workloads, including microsoft sql server, sap hana, ibm db2, and oracle that run performance intensive applications such as commerce platforms, erp systems, and health record systems

question: what are the various storage options available on r5b instances?
answer: r5b instances are ebs-optimized by default and offer up to 60,000 mbps of dedicated ebs bandwidth and 260k iops for both encrypted and unencrypted ebs volumes

question: when should i use r5b instances?
answer: customers running workloads such as large relational databases and data analytics that want to take advantage of the increased ebs storage network performance can use r5b instances to deliver higher performance and bandwidth

question: what are amazon ec2 x2gd instances?
answer: amazon ec2 x2gd instances are the next generation of memory-optimized instances powered by aws-designed arm-based aws graviton2 processors

question: what workloads are suited for x2gd instances?
answer: x2gd is ideal for customers with arm-compatible memory bound scale-out workloads such as redis and memcached in-memory databases, that need low latency memory access and benefit from more memory per vcpu

question: when should customer use x2gd instances compared to x1 and r-family of instances?
answer: x2gd instances are suitable for arm-compatible memory bound scale-out workloads such as in-memory databases, memory analytics applications, open-source relational database workloads, eda workloads, and large caching servers

question: when should i use x1 instances?
answer: x1 instances are ideal for running in-memory databases like sap hana, big data processing engines like apache spark or presto, and high performance computing (hpc) applications

question: when should i use x1e instances?
answer: x1e instances are ideal for running in-memory databases like sap hana, high-performance databases and other memory optimized enterprise applications

question: how do x1 and x1e instances differ?
answer: x1e instances offer 32gb of memory per vcpu whereas x1 instances offer 16gb of memory per vcpu

question: what operating systems are supported on x1 and x1e instances?
answer: x1 and x1e instances provide high number of vcpus, which might cause launch issues in some linux operating systems that have a lower vcpu limit

question: what storage options are available for x1 customers?
answer: x1 instances offer ssd based instance store, which is ideal for temporary storage of information such as logs, buffers, caches, temporary tables, temporary computational data, and other temporary content

question: how do i build cost-effective failover solution on x1 and x1e instances?
answer: you can design simple and cost-effective failover solutions on x1 instances using amazon ec2 auto recovery, an amazon ec2 feature that is designed to better manage failover upon instance impairment

question: what is a dense-storage instance?
answer: dense-storage instances are designed for workloads that require high sequential read and write access to very large data sets, such as hadoop distributed computing, massively parallel processing data warehousing, and log processing applications

question: how do dense-storage instances compare to high i/o instances?
answer: high i/o instances (i2, i3, i3en) are targeted at workloads that demand low latency and high random i/o in addition to moderate storage density and provide the best price/iops across other ec2 instance types

answer: d2 and h1 instances provide notifications for hardware failures

answer: each hdd-storage instance type (h1, d2, d3, and d3en) is ebs-optimized by default

question: can i launch d2 instances as amazon ebs-optimized instances?
answer: each d2 instance type is ebs-optimized by default

question: are dense-storage instances offered in ec2 classic?
answer: the current generation of dense-storage instances (d2 instances) can be launched in both ec2-classic and amazon vpc

question: what is a high i/o instance?

question: are all features of amazon ec2 available for high i/o instances?
answer: high i/o instances support all amazon ec2 features

question: is there a limit on the number of high i/o instances i can use?
answer: currently, you can launch 2 i3

question: how many iops can i3.16.xlarge instances deliver?
answer: using hvm amis, high i/o i3 instances can deliver up to 3

question: what is the sequential throughput of i3 instances?
answer: the maximum sequential throughput, measured at 128k block sizes is 16 gb/s read throughput and 6

question: do high i/o instances provide any failover mechanisms or redundancy?
answer: like other amazon ec2 instance types, instance storage on i3 and i3en instances persists during the life of the instance

question: do high i/o instances support trim?
answer: the trim command allows the operating system to inform ssds which blocks of data are no longer considered in use and can be wiped internally

question: how many iops can i3en.24xlarge instances deliver?
answer: using hvm amis, high i/o i3en instances can deliver up to 2 million iops measured at 100% random reads using 4kb block sizes, and up to 1

question: what is the sequential throughput of i3en instances?
answer: the maximum sequential throughput, measured at 128k block sizes is 16 gb/s read throughput and 8 gb/s write throughput

answer: yes; data written onto the storage volumes will be encrypted at rest using aes-256-xts

question: what happens to my data when a system terminates?
answer: the data stored on a local instance store will persist only as long as that instance is alive

question: what are throughput optimized hdd (st1) and cold hdd (sc1) volume types?

question: do you support multiple instances accessing a single volume?

answer: no, ebs snapshots are only available through the amazon ec2 apis

question: are snapshots versioned? can i read an older snapshot to do a point-in-time recovery?

question: how can i find what amazon ebs snapshots are shared globally?

question: do you offer encryption on amazon ebs volumes and snapshots?

question: how can i find a list of amazon public data sets?

question: where can i learn more about ebs?
answer: you can visit the amazon ebs faq page

question: how do i access my file system from outside my vpc?
answer: amazon ec2 instances within your vpc can access your file system directly, and amazon ec2 classic instances outside your vpc can mount a file system via classiclink

question: where can i learn more about efs?
answer: you can visit the amazon efs faq page

question: what encryption algorithm is used to encrypt amazon ec2 nvme instance storage?
answer: amazon ec2 nvme instance storage is encrypted using an xts-aes-256 block cipher

question: are encryption keys unique to an instance or a particular device for nvme instance storage?
answer: encryption keys are securely generated within the nitro hardware module, and are unique to each nvme instance storage device that is provided with an ec2 instance

question: what is the lifetime of encryption keys on nvme instance storage?
answer: all keys are irrecoverably destroyed on any de-allocation of the storage, including instance stop and instance terminate actions

question: can i disable nvme instance storage encryption?
answer: no, nvme instance storage encryption is always on, and cannot be disabled

question: do the published iops performance numbers on i3 and i3en include data encryption?
answer: yes, the documented iops numbers for i3 and i3en nvme instance storage include encryption

question: does amazon ec2 nvme instance storage support aws key management service (kms)?
answer: no, disk encryption on nvme instance storage does not support integration with aws kms system

question: why should i use efa?
answer: efa brings the scalability, flexibility, and elasticity of cloud to tightly-coupled hpc applications

question: what types of applications can benefit from using efa?
answer: high performance computing (hpc) applications distribute computational workloads across a cluster of instances for parallel processing

question: which instance types support efa?

answer: an ena eni provides traditional ip networking features necessary to support vpc networking

answer: in order to help ensure our customers are efficiently using the elastic ip addresses, we impose a small hourly charge for each address when it is not associated to a running instance

answer: no, you do not need an elastic ip address for all your instances

question: do i need to pay an additional fee to use enhanced networking?

question: can i automatically scale amazon ec2 auto scaling groups?

question: what is vm import/export?
answer: vm import/export enables customers to import virtual machine (vm) images in order to create amazon ec2 instances

question: what operating systems are supported?
answer: vm import/export currently supports windows and linux vms, including windows server 2003, windows server 2003 r2, windows server 2008, windows server 2012 r1, red hat enterprise linux (rhel) 5

question: what is vmdk?
answer: vmdk is a file format that specifies a virtual machine hard disk encapsulated within a single file

question: how do i prepare a vmdk file for import using the vmware vsphere client?
answer: the vmdk file can be prepared by calling file-export-export to ovf template in vmware vsphere client

question: what is vhd?
answer: vhd (virtual hard disk) is a file format that specifies a virtual machine hard disk encapsulated within a single file

question: how do i prepare a vhd file for import from citrix xen?
answer: open citrix xencenter and select the virtual machine you want to export

question: how do i prepare a vhd file for import from microsoft hyper-v?

question: are there any other requirements when exporting an ec2 instance using vm import/export?
answer: you can export running or stopped ec2 instances that you previously imported using vm import/export

question: can i export amazon ec2 instances that have one or more ebs data volumes attached?

question: what does it cost to import a virtual machine?
